reviewText:
I'm quite a big fan of the LEGO games, mainly for these three reasons: they're highly replayable, enjoyable and casual. Hours of gameplay can easily be put into a single LEGO game for unlocking extra collectables or other LEGO characters among many other things. Just like in other LEGO games, LEGO The Hobbit is an addictive and light-hearted experience that will take hours for LEGO- and Lord of the Rings-fans alike to complete and perfect, but that's also it's main problem just like with any previous LEGO title... it's more or less the same.

The Pros:
· LEGO The Hobbit stays true to the new popular prequel trilogy (The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey, The Hobbit: Desolation of Smaug and the upcoming The Hobbit: There and Back Again) in both story and lore. Just like in LEGO Lord of the Rings you'll play through the three movies (There and Back Again announced to be DLC when the final movie is released) with some added humorous elements, like silly LEGO figurines holding an umbrella above their heads in order to avoid being hit by falling bricks.
· Didn't get a chance to watch the movies? This game will tell you the same story with entertaining LEGO moments and buildable & destructable LEGO constructions to add a ton of extra content without ever forgetting about the story that needs to be told. Don't let that keep you from buying LEGO The Hobbit if you have already watched The Hobbit movies released so far though! I have seen both movies plenty of times (six times each) and I still find this game just as enjoyable if not a bit more entertaining than watching the movies. It adds an open world LEGO experience that stays true to both LEGO-imagination and the same beautiful world we've seen in The Hobbit and the Lord of the Rings trilogy by Peter Jackson.
· There's a ton of stuff to do, like collecting items for crafting (which is an entertaining new addition to the LEGO series), sidequests, replaying missions with certain characters in order to get all the level-specific collectables (for example: Legolas can create a staircase" of arrows and dwarves can't) or simply running around destroying constructions to collect LEGO studs that will help to fill up your Master Burglar meter. Still...

The Cons:
· That's more or less exactly what we've been doing in the past couple of LEGO games. For those who are not as interrested in the Lord of the Rings universe as I am among many many others

reviewText:
I cannot support the idea of buying 2/3 of a game.

There IS a lot to like in this game.  They added an attempt at a crafting system (extremely rudementary and not very well executed), and they finally allowed us to see what the characters can do as we select them from the big list.  But that's mostly because a majority of the characters are virtually the same.  Which is more the problem with the story than the game.  It has the same type of overworld as Lego LOTR, with questing and such.  Elements of the overworld unlock as you play through the story.

All in all, on a technical level, the game's a fairly fun Lego game.

But the failures come in the adaptation.  First off, they chose to model the game after the movies.  Because of course they did, if they followed the book instead people would be confused and scared and not want to give them money again.  So we have crap like the stupid barrel scene, and the really, REALLY badly done Lake-Town bit (and a level in this game that just never seems to end - much like the movie).  And if they had based it on the book, they could have actually FINISHED THE BLOODY STORY!

No, instead, we get 2/3 of the game.  And that's all there will ever be.  There is no DLC for the third movie (which would be a terrible precedent anyway).  There is no second game (which would be about as sorry as Lego Indiana Jones 2).  What we are left with is an eternally incomplete product because they felt the need to rush this game out the door.

Do not buy it.  There are plenty of other Lego games to play instead.  And if you have already played all of those, there are plenty of other video games period that are far more worth your time than this incomplete mess.

For Veteran Lego Player	Lego:The Hobbit is a lego game that is for sure, what it is not however is a main title in the Lego series. It is a tie-in for The Hobbit movie but it only covers movie 1 and movie 2 but not movie 3 which provides the conclusion for the main draw of the movie which is the dragon Smaug. Overall if you like Lego games I recommend skipping this one because while the game is fun it is rather repetitive and has the samey feeling from start to finish.

Now lets get on to the review. No screenshots due to terrible network.

Lego™ The Hobbit	Official Website: http://thehobbit.lego.com/en-us/
Developer: Traveller's Tale[PC], Feral Interactice[MAC]
Date of Release: 10 April 2014
Genre: Kids game, Lego, Adventure, Simple Puzzle	What is Lego™ The Hobbit? 	Lego™ The Hobbit follows Lego never ending formula of licensing popular movie, comic, franchise license and remaking the whole thing in the style of Lego bricks and character. This is their whole formula.

Lego™ The Hobbit is a movie tie in with The Hobbit movie although I must stress here that it is incomplete and will never be completed with the game only covering part 1 and 2 of the movie without the ending of 3. The game has you moving all over middle earth just like in the movie while interacting with Lego pieces and uncovering the storymode with the usual but less dose of Lego humour. Meanwhile read on. 	Option Menu	Good

Graphical Setting ☑
Resolution ☑
Controls [Rebindeable☑ Deadzone Adjustment for Controller☑] ☑
Audio, Music And Subtitle ☑

You will not be in want for sure in Lego™ The Hobbit setting menu since it has all your basic needs covered although do read on the control section for possible issue for KB+M user.	Graphics	Maintaining a steady 60 fps at top setting Lego™ The Hobbit texture looks beautiful enough at High although it does have a bit too much of a sheen and brown for my taste personally.

Any useable object will usually be placed as a Lego piece instead to mark it out. So for my verdict. In a game released in the year 2014 Lego™ The Hobbit is very beautiful albeit a bit brown. 	Music Audio	Average

They used movie voiceover for this version of Lego and it is good enough even if it lacks the mute charm of earlier Lego games.

For music and sound effect they mostly reuse it from the whole series with recognizable songs peppered throughout the game.	Controls	Average

KB+M
Forgot about it. The game uses KL;O for camera movement, JHYUI for action stuff and WASD for movement. While the controls can be change in the settings it is still rather awkward using the KB+M for this game especially since the mouse does not serve a function.

Controller
Meanwhile on the other hand the series had always emphasize more on using controllers and it shows. The game is more enjoyable when you plug in any compatible controller since the controls and prompt are within fingers reach without having to do the finger yoga maneuver.  	Gameplay	The game has you controlling several of The Hobbit cast as you go through the game in story mode.

Each level has you controlling a specific number of character each with a unique skill needed for the task ahead although once you completed the level you can just switch to any other character you unlocked at any time by using the freeplay mode which is helpful since some of the minikit for collection cannot be obtained via a single playthrough.

An example of the mechanic  would be switching to the guy with the axe to destroy weak block. Guy with chain to grapple and Elf to jump higher.

As stated earlier finishing the level once allows you to freeplay it again with any unlocked character.

The game is a semi open world based where you are funneled into the next area linearly but you could always backtrack and head out to other area for sidequest to complete. Sidequest also unlocks once you clear a level but they are usually quite simplistic utilizing the game forging and find an item process.

One of the puzzle requires you to quickly find a compatible pieces in a wheel formation for big reward although it does get repetitive fast which is true for most of the sidequest.

Annoyingly enough the fast travel option only unlocks halfway through the game which makes you not want to do the sidequest. Thankfully the material needed to advance the story are provided as oppose to needing to grind for it.	Conclusion	As a Lego game it is enjoyable but as part of the Lego series in the grand scheme it fell short quite a lot. Reused assets, repetitive gameplay with no breakup in mechanic and too much filler place this quite low on the list of Lego game which I recommend but ultimately the lack of any DLC for episode 3 of the movie prevents me from recommending this game heartedly.

Get it if you like LEGO games but otherwised get the more well established franchise over this one.

Scoring Methology:
-S-Rank: excellent
-A-Rank: very good
-B-Rank: solid
-C-Rank: satisfactory
-D-Rank: inferior

Verdict: C [An average Lego Experience]

reviewText:
Lego The Hobbit was released in April 2014 based on the first two Hobbit films, An Unexpected Journey and The Desolation of Smaug. This is only my second run through a LEGO game; my first being The Lego Movie so I am still quite an armature when it comes to the LEGO series.

The game play is lot of features from the previous game including a feature which you build a big Lego object out of bits of broken down objects that you have smashed up in the world. Each of the characters which you play have their own unique ability or weapon that gives them there on use and key element to you finishing each level or finding all of the hidden items in the game.  The game is split into sixteen chapters, each of which are connected by a huge map which you are able to explore in a free roam sort of mode. Between each main chapter's story, you are able to carry out side quests for other Lego characters throughout the world.

Story wise, it basically follows the story lines from the books/films. There are some small modification to fit events into a suitable number of chapters, as well as adding the increasingly well known Lego humor that we all love.  Sadly according to a number of sources across the net, there were plans to bring out some DLC for the final chapter in the story, but the idea appears to have been scraped so we won't get to see the final book/film in this series.

All of the audio in Lego The Hobbit is taken directly out of the film it self. Christopher Lee has the role of the narrator throughout the whole game as well.

This game does not carry any difficulty what-so-ever. You have unlimited lives so dying is not an issue. The main aim, apart from finishing the story of course, is to collect Lego bricks on each level in order to be the Master Builder" along with lots of other little collectibles such as special building kits
date: which can all be used to unlock hidden characters in the game.\n\nA playthrough the story mode of this game as well as a good portion of side quests took me twelve hours to complete. Once you finish the game you have the option to go back and finish the remaining quests
recommended: as well as free roam around all the levels replaying them to find the remaining hidden items and collectibles. This will probably add on another four or five hours worth of game play if you are the completionist sort.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
WHAT IS LEGO - The Hobbit?

Those of you who already played some LEGO games know that these games bring fantasy worlds to life and with the addition of open world in newer games it is almost perfect - if you don't mind things being made out of LEGO bricks. Beside story missions you have access to a large enough open world which you can enjoy and explore (fast travelling is added as an option after a certain story mission). There are collectibles to find, many characters to unlock and studs to collect so you can buy those characters and use them.

# Candy
LEGO - The Hobbit will provide hours of gameplay, either if you play alone or wth a friend (local co-op!). Its open world is amazing and you can spend a lot of time just wandering around and exploring the world of Middle-earth. Story missions which are well done are following the scenes from the movies and are filled with nice humour and charm. Using a controller is highly recommended (in all LEGO games) but you won't have problems if you are using a keyboard.

# Chilli
If you expect the whole trilogy - story missions only cover the first two movies. Disappointing as this may be you also need to know that beside the fact of you knowing that the story missions from the third movie aren't included, this game never feels incomplete nor it affects the open world in any way.  Another thing to consider for those who only played older LEGO games - characters aren't mute and with that said humour is a bit different so to those who loved that in older LEGO games this might be an issue. Last but not least (and something which doesn't have anything to do with this review or the game itself) - you can find in the store three dlc packs. They add nothing to the story and are only character and item packs. You won't miss anything by not having them but if you are still interested I would advise getting on a sale.

# 8.5 LEGO adventures out of 10
If the fact that this game doesn't include the third movie is a deal-breaker to you  - skip it. Otherwise, it is a great LEGO game and one of the best in my opinion.

reviewText:
LEGO The Hobbit is, first and foremost, a LEGO game. There isn't a great deal different from other LEGO titles, in both bad and good ways. If you've tried LEGO games before and found them dull, I don't think this one will change your mind, but if you have an obsession for collection, this game will probably serve you well.

First of all, some gripes. I really don't like how the game forces you to come back later and re-do things when you already have the means to complete them at your disposal, simply locked away. It takes advantage of a child's endless appetite for repetition (Pokemon, anyone?), but as an adult it gets frustrating at times. And speaking of frustrating, the game has some bugs too. I've had characters get stuck, once even in a game-breaking way in the middle of a story mission that locked out all buttons but Start and forced me to quit. The physics on hills and edges get weird sometimes and prevent you from jumping, which can sometimes lead to the stuck thing or lead to death in the middle of a jumping puzzle. I would also get random crashes for a while, which was fixed by turning off Raptr's integration completely, even the Track Gameplay part (the only part I actually use). And the end of the game cuts off at a really bad time, though that's not entirely their fault, since from what I understand the movie does too. Perhaps they should have waited for the third movie to come out to release this. Hopefully they put out some DLC to add in the final climax. It's literally only missing the last chapter or two from the book.

Now that I've gotten that out of the way, the game is still fun. It's still cathartic to beat up LEGO objects and watch them explode into fountains of loot and studs. The gradual ramp of power and wealth starts to get quite high near the end, and I feel a bit Smaug looking over my vast collection of items and riches. Okay, I admit that pun was terrible. Moving on. None of the missions, quests, or puzzles are particularly difficult or complex, but are still fun nonetheless. Suitably accessible for a child but still enjoyable for an adult, a good balance. I'm about 28 hours in and I still haven't gotten tired of it. The bits of humor injected into the game here and there are a nice touch as well. My favorite gag is Azog's missing hand actually following him around and constantly taunting him. Great way to add flavor to the original movie script. And the voice acting clips taken from the movie are a nice touch to telling the story as well, as opposed to the silent approach of early LEGO games.

By no means is LEGO The Hobbit without flaws, but if you're a fan of Traveller's Tales style of collect-a-thon games, this will be a shining Arkenstone in your collection. I picked it up for $5 on sale and more than got my money's worth out of it. Again, if you're tired of the LEGO formula or just really hate Tolkien it's probably a safe pass, but for everyone else, I'd definitely recommend giving it a try.

Amazing game!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Many people say that this is a really bad game and that it is not going strictly towards the story line in many parts like bilbo having to construct the answers instead of saying them in the riddle game with gollum and that ori kills the great goblin instead of gandalf! reviewText:
LEGO The Hobbit is on one hand a great improvement over LEGO Lord of the Rings, and on the other it is by far the buggiest LEGO game I have played.

TT Games addressed three of my main complaints with LEGO LOTR: lack of a mini-map (this was introduced in LEGO Marvel) and lack of the ability to summon a horse to travel faster.  Both of these things help immensely with navigating the game world.  The other major fix is game performance.  Both LEGO LOTR and LEGO Marvel stuttered badly moving around the game world.  They finally seem to have fixed the problem with this game so it runs nice and smoothly like it should.  Otherwise, the game is very similar to LEGO LOTR as expected, though some new character abilities were introduced.  One of the main complaints I have read about the game is that the dwarves, who have many different abilities, are difficult to tell apart but I didn't have much trouble after the first hour or so.

If you've played other LEGO games, you should understand how they play and this one isn't really any different.  What is different is the bugs.  While I haven't played many LEGO games, the bugs have been pretty minimal.  In this one however, I ran into numerous game-breaking bugs that required quitting and reloading my save.  I had the fast travel system stall so I was stuck in midair, I've randomly lost the ability to open the map, and I even had the blacksmithing minigame freeze up on me.  At one point I managed to get a character stuck during a combat QTE sequence in a position where the sequence wouldn't complete, so it kept repeating endlessly.  All of these things happened several times throughout my playthrough and were quite frustrating.

Despite the bugs, the game is still enjoyable and is definitely recommended for LEGO and LOTR fans.

Otherwise, the game is very similar to LEGO LOTR as expected, though some new character abilities were introduced.  One of the main complaints I have read about the game is that the dwarves, who have many different abilities, are difficult to tell apart but I didn't have much trouble after the first hour or so.

If you've played other LEGO games, you should understand how they play and this one isn't really any different.  What is different is the bugs.  While I haven't played many LEGO games, the bugs have been pretty minimal.  In this one however, I ran into numerous game-breaking bugs that required quitting and reloading my save.  I had the fast travel system stall so I was stuck in midair, I've randomly lost the ability to open the map, and I even had the blacksmithing minigame freeze up on me.  At one point I managed to get a character stuck during a combat QTE sequence in a position where the sequence wouldn't complete, so it kept repeating endlessly.  All of these things happened several times throughout my playthrough and were quite frustrating.

Despite the bugs, the game is still enjoyable and is definitely recommended for LEGO and LOTR fans.

reviewText: I'm a MASSIVE fan of the LEGO Games. I've completed all of them 100% since the beginning (excluding City Undercover for the Wii U) 'm working my way through this one and MARVEL atm and I can safely say that this one is one of my favourites alongside LotR. My last bug bear with this game is that there is no Online Co-op. There is same system co-op, but I think that TT games should try to incorporate this into their future LEGO games as this would just make this game the best game on the planet (although its pretty damn close as it is). Overall, if you love LEGO and the LotR or Hobbit world, then this is a no brainer. Tbh, even if you dont particularly like LotR, you should still buy this just for the laughs and thrills you will get along the way :)

reviewText:
An elf, a man and a dwarf walk into a bar. The hobbit laughs and walks under it.
Lego the Hobbit (LtH for short) is another prime example of Lego's continuing creativity. This game has variety, action, adventure, questing, humor--all the things I've come to expect in their recent games. LtH is a decent retelling of the movie, which is a not-so-decent retelling of the original fictional novel by J.R.R Tolkien. Though this game was a pleasurable experience for me, I have to admit that it has some large flaws.
First, the fact that this game only encompasses the first two out of three movies made by New Line Cinema. The Battle of FIve Armies was originally intended to be released as a DLC for this game, but Warner Bros. canceled this development. So now, we have a game that leaves off with a cliff-hanger, and no way to resolve that cliff-hanger besides watching the movies.
Second, the character customization. Every modern Lego game has one--a place where you can create your own Lego figure, and play with them in the game. In the past, this was an amazing feature in Lego games. However, in LtH, the character customization is somewhat lacking. This game does not let you equip a weapon or cloak to your custom character (no capes I guess?). This was extremely disappointing to me, as outfitting my character with cool cloaks and weapons had been my favorite part of Lego games in the past. While the customizer in itself has no lack of Lego parts to use on your figure, weapons and cloaks are not allowed >:(
Third, the difficulty of finding secrets. In the open world, secrets and mysteries abound. In previous Lego games, the variety of secrets was perhaps not as big (except in Lego LOTR), and they could all be obtained with relative ease. In LtH, secrets stay secret if you aren't extremely persistant. Just finding the blacksmith so I could craft mithril items took me the better part of two days. The instructions are rather vague, and certain puzzles and quests are extremely difficult to complete. This will be sure to annoy younger kids after a while.
Aside from these three flaws though, LtH is an extraordinary game for younger kids into the lore of Middle Earth. The story is pretty decent, and the combat is satisfying without being bloody or gory. This is perhaps Lego's strongest point--the ability to create massive-scale battles that young children will be able to partake in without worrying about gory imagery or blood. Overall, this is a good adventure game, but I would recommend waiting until a sale to grab it. The DLCs are ok, but I'd wait until a sale for those ones too.
8/10 a decent game.

reviewText: This game isn't necessarily bad. It does a great job of capturing the feeling of adventure, and the battles can feel quite epic and somewhat intense. However it has a few hiccups in which I would only recommend someone to buy this game if on sale so they don't feel cheated. The boss-ish kind of battles would feel more epic if it was a little more challenging, since upon completion you are left feeling not too satisfied. The biggest gripe I have with the game is how it feels incomplete since it only inculdes the story of the 1st and 2nd movie. Hopefully a free DLC will be released when the time comes, but there are no garentees that one will be released at all. In the end, I would recommend you wait for a sale if you're really interested in this game.

reviewText: I struggled to know whether to recommend this game or not. On the one hand, it can be very fun, as with all Lego games: good humour, good level designs, completionists dream, etc. However, the amount of times I wanted to throw my controller at the TV in frustration was just ridiculous. The game contantly froze or had game-breaking glitches; the addition of crafting mini-games was silly (especially because the piece you needed was frequently impossible to see and looked entirely different from the picture given); platforming is still a nightmare, with poor clipping and hit detection; and at one point I had to drop the screen resolution to its lowest in order to fix an upscaling glitch that prevented certain actions to be performed. For some strange reason they removed key quality-of-life features from previous entries, and they managed to find the most annoying way possible to force people to use the character customiser feature.\n\nDefinitely my least favourite of the Lego games so far where the annoyances finally outweighed the fun factor. I would say play it if you enjoy Lego games, but be prepared for some serious frustration if you're committed to 100% completion.

reviewText: The levels are really good, and the graphics are the best yet. But once you finish the levels, and start on the remaining 3/4, it's just annoying. The camera swoops around at the slightest provocation, so that you either fall off what you were standing on, or can't see anything. Any character you control will automatically target the nearest NPC instead of the lego item you want to smash (Saruman himself is unable to attack anything he is standing next to; you have to walk away, then hope that the other character doesn't move to stand in front of it). Travelling is tedious; you will always start at the far end of the map (where the story ended), and going anywhere is slow and repetitive. Finally, the lego building thing that was so good within levels now slows down everything else you do. You want to forge a mithril item? Have you collected 50 carrots, a bunch of rocks, some copper, and a stack of red gems? Go do that first! You want to help a guy build a thing? Do you have 60 pieces of silver, and some wood, and some green gems?\nSo, initially I'd have given it 8 or 9 out of 10, but my best estimate at this point (31% completion) is that it would be lucky to get a 6 from me.

O Game Lego: The Hobbit veio com a proposta de trazer a história do livro de J. R. R. Tolkien para o universo de peças de LEGO , oq eu tenho a dizer... Bem a adaptação dicou Boa. O jeito que foi contada , detalhes , claro que faltou algumas coisas que não podem ser recriadas com a peçinhas , mais no geral o jogo está bom , e agora uma análise minha sobre o game:

Enredo: 9.0/10 (O enredo foi focado nos dois primeiros filme do universo de ''O Hobbit'' sendo eles: ''Uma Jornada Inesperada'' e ''A Desolação de Smaug'', foram bem adaptados e são mostradas as partes mais importantes de ambos os filmes , mais ai me vem a pergunta: Agora com o lançamento do filme ''A Batalha Dos Cinco Exécitos'' como iremos fazer para jogar o terceiro filme no game?, quem já possui o jogo irá ganha-lo como uma DLC gratuita ou teremos que pagar para joga-lo?).

Gráficos: 8.5/10 (Os Gráficos estão praticamente os mesmos de outros jogos da LEGO, o game LEGO: The Hobbit é um dos games mais recentes da LEGO, e os gráficos dele são facilmente comparados aos do game LEGO: The Lord of The Rings (Antecessor do game, que conta a história dos 3 filmes do de ''O Senhor dos Anéis''), Houve pouca Melhora Gráfica, mais não posso deixar de falar que houve uma melhora...Porém...muito pequena).

Trilha Sonora: 9.5/10 (Foram Usadas Musicas de ambas as Franquias Tanto as de ''O Senhor dos Anéis'' como a de ''O Hobbit'', e para quem é Fã e já viu os Filmes, Não preciso nem dizer que é uma Trilha Sonora Epica...).

Efeitos Sonoros: 8.0/10 (São bons, como peças de LEGO quebrando e de armas como espadas e arcos... mais nada demais...).

I bought this game after finishing LEGO Lord of the rings 100% just because how great the LOTR was and the Hobbit did not dissapoint me.

The Hobbit game story is from the first two hobbit movies leaving the third hobbit movie a possible DLC or a new game entirely. Also minable stones for minerals and other goods. These loots are used to build up stuff and completeing various side quests.

Negative things about LEGO Hobbit:

3. Game speed seems to vary alot like in a badly emulated console games on PC. Sometimes the map navigation magnifying glass goes wayyy too fast to select items from map. Also those lego building minigames the selection is sometimes ridiculously hard to make when the selector goes too fast. Not sure if this is a factor when mining stones, but they seem ok.
4. Lots of little annoying bugs, like switching character just doesn't work unless you change a scenery by flying or something like that.
5. Changing day/night time is annoying. First have to find a camp somewhere and then watch a stupid sausage grilling moment that takes too long.

I would rate this game 3.5/5. It is a very good game with some minor bugs here and there.

reviewText:
[Update] This is by far the most unstable, bug-riddled, glitched, crashy mess I've ever seen in a Lego game. It feels like they ran out of funding 3/4 of the way through production and shipped what they had.

Lego: The Hobbit is not a bad game by Lego game standards - it has continued to progress the formula, including the 'build minigame' from the Lego Movie game, adding team-up attacks between some characters and a resource mechanic (which perpetuates the grind, but is new nonetheless).

What this game -doesn't- have is an ending. It just stops after one mission with no conclusion to the plot, then the credits roll. That's it. Now go do the other 75% of the game that is open-world challenges and fetch-quests. You might think the character roster is up to par, but in reality 50% of the listed characters are just alternate costumes - they are no longer stacked per-character like the Harry Potter games - which also leads to having two of the same character in play at once.

Lego games are no stranger to bugs, but this is the first game that I've had multiple encounters with game-ending bugs. Be it being permamently stuck in an animation, the fast-travel eagle freezing in mid-air or the forging mini-game being incompleteable. These are not crashes, but event chains simply not working and requiring the game to be quit and restarted. There are also numerious examples of the game temporarily freezing or slowing down, but these don't end the game.

Many other people have said it, so I'll be breif. This game is unfinished. It has polish, the gameplay is as it has ever been, the world is expansive and there certainly isn't a shortage of things to do, but it feels as though the filler content vastly outweighs the structured content, as there are a number of abilities and character-types that simply do not appear in the main story, and only become accessable after you finish what story there is.

In short, there are better Lego games out there, and better ones will be coming, so you're better off getting one that feels like it's all there.

This game is basically Lego Skyrim. Which is awesome. There's an open world map to explore, tons of side quests to do, and lots of weapons and armor pieces available to customize whatever character you play as. Plus the blocky Lego-ness of the game makes it really low-stress to play. There's no blood or tense gameplay here. Just hours of good fun.

One common complaint about the Lego video games is that after awhile, they all tend to feel the same. In this particular game however, the makers tried to make it feel a little more special than usual by adding a few new gameplay features...like mining, armor/weapon collecting, food/supplies collecting, and smithing (which was also present in the Lego Lord of the Rings game). These features really add to the gameplay, giving you an additional reward beyond money for every bush, tree, boulder, or piece of furniture you smash. The mining feature is not the easiest to use, however, since it relies on really precise timing and an instantly responsive controller. But it still isn't impossible to collect all the elements you need to complete the quests or smith the various items.

If you enjoy any of the Lego games, I would highly reccommend this one. Like I said, it's like Skyrim, but Lego. 10/10 for Lego Hobbit.

A must for any LEGO/ Tolkien fan!

Content:

The game takes you through the Hobbit movies. On your journey you will meet interesting characters with brilliant abilities and visit beautiful places. Once you finish the game there are many other things to do in Middle-Earth...

You can:

Explore the entire journey  ( and a few places from LOTR like Moria and Lorien ) again in Free Roam.
Accept quests from the people scattered across the land for resources.
Trade unwanted rescources for better ones.
Forge items of Mithril in Bree.
Customize a character in Lake Town.
Unlock and buy extra characters like Gollum, Saruman and Sauron (  to unlock Sauron at any time use the following code: oara3d )
Jump on the back of an eagle for a fast way around the kingdom.
Replay completed levels.
Jump forward or back in time using campsites.

Gameplay:

Good with a fairly fast computer, amazing with a gaming one. Each level features different puzzles and funny cutscenes with real audio and dialogue from the movies. Each of the 13 dwarves have unique abilities like:

Using a bow and arrow to shoot targets ( Kili )
Eating food on special picnic mats and allowing the rest of the company to jump on him like a trampoline ( Bombur )
Mining rare resources like gold and ruby ( Bofur )
Using his staff to dwarf stack ( Gloin )
Using his flail to attach to gold hooks and bring down high items ( Dori )
Using his warhammer to push items ( Dwalin )

Pros:

Free Roam
Long levels that pack lots of puzzles in
Many characters to collect
The barrel scene from Desolation of Smaug ( available at all good Thranduil's Kingdoms )
Eagle Flying
Horse/ warg riding
Boat using
Beorn the shape changer's special ability - turning into a fast and strong bear!

Cons:

No Battle Of The Five Armies gameplay yet ( coming soon as DLC )
Middle-Earth is dangerous at night ( orcs come out!)
Had a few problems with shutting computer down in game after saving at a save point - don't do that if you get it!

Conclusion:

I would rate this 9/10 at the moment because there is no Battle Of Five Armies gameplay yet!

Hope you liked my review!

reviewText:
I had a lot of fun playing this game in co-op, just like I mostly enjoyed LEGO Lord of the Rings. Unfortunately, I'm mostly left with negatives.

The story of LEGO The Hobbit is told like in LLOTR - original movie dialogue is used to voice the characters, while their mostly ridiculous animated behaviour makes for a humorous parody. I found that LEGO the Hobbit can't quite keep up with LOTR in that respect tough, just like the Hobbit movies seemed not quite able to capture what made the LOTR movies great. Luckily, the gameplay holds up just the same.

Compared to LLOTR, this game has some additonal character special abilities. Small characters now buddy up -- or dwarf up if you like -- with a second small party member to destroy particularly tough walls or deal damage to stunned bosses. With the slingshot, there is now another type of ranged weapon to be used in puzzles. Instead of pushing large blocks slows over checkered floors, Dwahlin, your Dwarven heavyweight, will now instead smash boulders along slides. That skill, just like the ability to mine ores, is curiously exclusive to one character throughout the whole story. And while all Dwarves can buddy up, most of them have abilities that only they possess. Combined with the fact that that the character selection wheel now accesses your inventory, you'll spend most of your time in this game swapping around the party. Even tough it's clear from some of the unique animation of the characters, that the developers wanted to give them meaning, some, just like in the movies, are left with a secondary role. One tends to wonder why the three dwarves whose sole special ability is that they can stand on top of each other, cannot fill the role of a second miner, shooter or rope-carrier.

Like in LLOTR, you'll need to make use of these abilities not just during the story missions but also when replaying a mission in free play and when attempting side-quests in the overworld. Compared to LLOTR, your access to the world until the end of the game is even more restricted, as there are seldom more than 5 characters available for you to use. This means you pretty much have to finish the story before attempting the side quests. This means that there are rarely opportunities where you can finish stuff around the world on your way to another mission and basically restricts you to exploring the world after the story is over.

The last and probably most damning point is, as other user reviews have mentioned, that the game is unfinished. It plays fine until you get to the part which is the end of the second movie and the game does not go on from there. The publisher, Warner Bros., stated that it intended to release an expansion to the game for the third movie. But this expansion is no longer forthcoming. The story ends at a cliffhanger and even though I'm sure most people know the cliffhanger is resolved, (the game being based on a children's book, it's not exaclty difficult) the player is still left with a feeling of incompleteness that will probably keep most people from going into free play mode. The hardcore collectors, however, will find lots of quests and things to do to keep them interested after the story has reached the apparent end.

Bottom line, if you're looking for more LEGO game action, just like the LEGO titles you've played before, you probably will get some enjoyment from this title. Otherwise, this game will probably miss the mark for you.

Lego: The Hobbit, is a very good game. I bought it without having watched the movie, and having greatly enjoyed the books. I was unable to tell which of the plot changes were made by Jackson, and which by Lego, but I thoroughly enjoyed myself, and I recommend the game. reviewText:
I picked this game up on sale purely due to the nostalgia I had toward previous lego games (mainly Lego Star Wars). Those games were great in two ways. They had a lot of replayability for guy like me who likes to unlock all the characters. They also had a great sense of humor in regard to the source material.

Let me explain that sense of humor a little. None of the characters ever spoke. They made sounds and displayed various cute animations thus showing the plot of the movie rather than telling us anything. As a result, those old games were great.

While Lego the Hobbit does maintain its replayability, it lacks any of the sense of humor of the original games. Long cutscenes clutter the entire beginning of the game (That's all I've played), all of which are narrated. The narration takes away from the original style and replaces the feel of the original games with something that very clearly feels like I'm just being shown a worse version of the film.

Furthermore, the old Star Wars games cost less than this and covered three movies (and 6 if you got the complete pack).  So if you do the math, $19.99 for a bad game covering 1 movie? Not a good deal.

In conclusion, I give this 3/10. If you really enjoyed the movie and either read or don't want to read the book, this may be a not awful way for you to get some more out of the franchise maybe? But only if you really must have more. Otherwise, avoid this purchase.

It's a bit of a shame, really. This is the first of the Lego games I can't whole-heartedly recommend. They're all a lot of fun, especially for just casual playing with friends, bit this one lets the side down.

It builds on Lego Lord of the Rings, with many of the same gameplay mechanics and similar voice acting dubbed in from the movies. As a game, it's mostly playable, but some of the mechanics are a little confusing. The inventory system is marginally harder to use and the system where Dwarves 'buddy up' to complete tasks is not amazingly well implemented. But that's not the biggest issue. By far the biggest issue is that this game doesn't include events from the 3rd Hobbit movie. It just ends with the events of the second one and leaves it at that. This is disappointing because we were led to believe there would be DLC which would patch in the third movie, but that was officially denied by the developers.

Don't get me wrong, it's a competent Lego game with it's own pluses and minuses, but not enough to recommend it. Go get Lego LotR, possibly the best Lego game yet, or Lego Star Wars, missing some of the extra mechanics, but still an absolute classic.

Before you get the pitchforks and torches to come after me for recommending this game, hear me out:

I recommend this game ONLY if you COMPLETELY, 110% understand that this game is not finished. It never will be finished. So, it is what it is. Plus you would have to get the game for super cheap (Hopefully below $4.99, but I don't think LEGO games go lower than that).

The Good:
I love LEGO games. Each one does a great job combining the original story of the movie it was based on, as well as adding their own spin with LEGO humor. The Hobbit is no exception. I recently started playing The Lord of the Rings, and am able to compare their progression from one to the other. The Hobbit feels a little more refined in gameplay, and they added a few other fun aspects that I felt were done better than The Lord of the Rings. The Hobbit does a good job with what was from the first 2 movies, and adding humor to things along the way. They also have a bunch of extra content that will keep you busy for many hours. They even have a day/night cycle. So, when you think you've done all of the extra content, you in fact are only about halfway done with the extra content. There are also a TON of extra characters. 90% of them aren't needed, but they are fun to unlock and run around the world with.

The Bad:
As I mentioned before, this game is not complete.The game ends with Smaug flying towards Laketown to attack it. And....that's it. Roll Credits. Congratulations, you beat The Hobbit. I would have been somewhat happy if they had just included one more mission where you take down Smaug, because it is after all called The Hobbit" not "...and Battle of the Five Armies". From what I have read online they had every intention of including content from "Battle of the Five Armies". However somewhere down the road someone made the decision to not develop that content. Is that acceptable for a game company to abandon a project 2/3 of the way done and say "Here ya go
date: this is all you get"? Absolutely not. That's why I recommend only getting the game when it is CHEAP. Cheap development practices should mean they will charge the customer a cheap price. reviewText:
I had a lot of fun playing this game in co-op, just like I mostly enjoyed LEGO Lord of the Rings. Unfortunately, I'm mostly left with negatives.

The story of LEGO The Hobbit is told like in LLOTR - original movie dialogue is used to voice the characters, while their mostly ridiculous animated behaviour makes for a humorous parody. I found that LEGO the Hobbit can't quite keep up with LOTR in that respect tough, just like the Hobbit movies seemed not quite able to capture what made the LOTR movies great. Luckily, the gameplay holds up just the same.

Compared to LLOTR, this game has some additonal character special abilities. Small characters now buddy up -- or dwarf up if you like -- with a second small party member to destroy particularly tough walls or deal damage to stunned bosses. With the slingshot, there is now another type of ranged weapon to be used in puzzles. Instead of pushing large blocks slows over checkered floors, Dwahlin, your Dwarven heavyweight, will now instead smash boulders along slides. That skill, just like the ability to mine ores, is curiously exclusive to one character throughout the whole story. And while all Dwarves can buddy up, most of them have abilities that only they possess. Combined with the fact that that the character selection wheel now accesses your inventory, you'll spend most of your time in this game swapping around the party. Even tough it's clear from some of the unique animation of the characters, that the developers wanted to give them meaning, some, just like in the movies, are left with a secondary role. One tends to wonder why the three dwarves whose sole special ability is that they can stand on top of each other, cannot fill the role of a second miner, shooter or rope-carrier.

Like in LLOTR, you'll need to make use of these abilities not just during the story missions but also when replaying a mission in free play and when attempting side-quests in the overworld. Compared to LLOTR, your access to the world until the end of the game is even more restricted, as there are seldom more than 5 characters available for you to use. This means you pretty much have to finish the story before attempting the side quests. This means that there are rarely opportunities where you can finish stuff around the world on your way to another mission and basically restricts you to exploring the world after the story is over.

The last and probably most damning point is, as other user reviews have mentioned, that the game is unfinished. It plays fine until you get to the part which is the end of the second movie and the game does not go on from there. The publisher, Warner Bros., stated that it intended to release an expansion to the game for the third movie. But this expansion is no longer forthcoming. The story ends at a cliffhanger and even though I'm sure most people know the cliffhanger is resolved, (the game being based on a children's book, it's not exaclty difficult) the player is still left with a feeling of incompleteness that will probably keep most people from going into free play mode. The hardcore collectors, however, will find lots of quests and things to do to keep them interested after the story has reached the apparent end.

Bottom line, if you're looking for more LEGO game action, just like the LEGO titles you've played before, you probably will get some enjoyment from this title. Otherwise, this game will probably miss the mark for you.

reviewText:
This game is basically Lego Skyrim. Which is awesome. There's an open world map to explore, tons of side quests to do, and lots of weapons and armor pieces available to customize whatever character you play as. Plus the blocky Lego-ness of the game makes it really low-stress to play. There's no blood or tense gameplay here. Just hours of good fun.

One common complaint about the Lego video games is that after awhile, they all tend to feel the same. In this particular game however, the makers tried to make it feel a little more special than usual by adding a few new gameplay features...like mining, armor/weapon collecting, food/supplies collecting, and smithing (which was also present in the Lego Lord of the Rings game). These features really add to the gameplay, giving you an additional reward beyond money for every bush, tree, boulder, or piece of furniture you smash. The mining feature is not the easiest to use, however, since it relies on really precise timing and an instantly responsive controller. But it still isn't impossible to collect all the elements you need to complete the quests or smith the various items.

If you enjoy any of the Lego games, I would highly reccommend this one. Like I said, it's like Skyrim, but Lego. 10/10 for Lego Hobbit.

reviewText:
[Update] This is by far the most unstable, bug-riddled, glitched, crashy mess I've ever seen in a Lego game. It feels like they ran out of funding 3/4 of the way through production and shipped what they had.

Lego: The Hobbit is not a bad game by Lego game standards - it has continued to progress the formula, including the 'build minigame' from the Lego Movie game, adding team-up attacks between some characters and a resource mechanic (which perpetuates the grind, but is new nonetheless).

What this game -doesn't- have is an ending. It just stops after one mission with no conclusion to the plot, then the credits roll. That's it. Now go do the other 75% of the game that is open-world challenges and fetch-quests. You might think the character roster is up to par, but in reality 50% of the listed characters are just alternate costumes - they are no longer stacked per-character like the Harry Potter games - which also leads to having two of the same character in play at once.

Lego games are no stranger to bugs, but this is the first game that I've had multiple encounters with game-ending bugs. Be it being permamently stuck in an animation, the fast-travel eagle freezing in mid-air or the forging mini-game being incompleteable. These are not crashes, but event chains simply not working and requiring the game to be quit and restarted. There are also numerious examples of the game temporarily freezing or slowing down, but these don't end the game.

Many other people have said it, so I'll be breif. This game is unfinished. It has polish, the gameplay is as it has ever been, the world is expansive and there certainly isn't a shortage of things to do, but it feels as though the filler content vastly outweighs the structured content, as there are a number of abilities and character-types that simply do not appear in the main story, and only become accessable after you finish what story there is.

In short, there are better Lego games out there, and better ones will be coming, so you're better off getting one that feels like it's all there.

reviewText:
I tend to greatly enjoy Lego games, but this particular one leaves a bitter taste in my mouth.

The gameplay itself is fair enough; it's an enjoyable puzzle platformer set to Tolkien's wonderful universe, and I believe you'll get your money's worth in terms of entertainment - however, there are two reasons that makes me give it a downvote.

First, the story mode only includes the tales of the first two movies. That means it ends rather abruptly at a cliffhanger, just like the second movie did. Given that story mode is only part of the gameplay, with the greater world of puzzles still being good value, I'm almost willing to overlook this fact.

What I can't ignore, however, is that some of the world puzzles are buggy or outright broken. Some can be played around, others cannot - in particular the Mithril Megapult schematics puzzle. This one is completely unobtainable for me due to a bug with the cave door it hides behind; it is a well-known bug, and none of the workaround suggestions I've found have fixed the issue I'm having. That means I'll never be able to actually complete the game, and that makes me feel cheated even more than the 'only two of three movies' story mode bit does.

All in all, a decent game brought down by some really annoying flaws. Given the title's age, I don't think it likely they'll ever be fixed, which is a pity.

Really great game. I'm also really glad I chose this game in particular from the Lego franchise to be my first. Very friendly to those who are new to it. Note : I played both singleplayer and splitscreen with my girlfriend (around 20 together, 30 solo), and 100%d the game. Ran on 4k DSR. GTX970, FX8320. -Looks great graphically for a Lego game.
-Performs even better than it looks. Confirmed in 4k.
-Story is very similar to the originals, but with quirky twists. Very enjoyable for all.

-RPG hoarders heaven, you collect tons of studs (currency), mithril bricks, etc. (Kinda like Ratchet and Clank)
-Unlockables at every turn. Seriously, constant new character unlocks and such. Loads of content. LOADS.
-FAST TRAVEL IS SO CONVINIENT, like for real. Select, choose a spot with an eagle statue, done.
-Splitscreeeeeeeen.

_/Cons\_
-AWFUL camera movement.
-Disorienting splitscreen splitting. (Particularly using menus)
-Gets grindy after about 70% completion. (Farming remaining mithril blocks, red blocks, etc.)
-All the fun content is SEVERELY hard to discover. I didn't know about so much until the end of the completion.
-Glitch heaven, though I want to note that any glitches are very minor as the autosave feature kicks butt.
